Information

This was the Object Oriented Programming and Design class's final. This was supposed to be a simple project to end the quarter with only a couple of weeks to work on it, but also something difficult enough for us to display it in project showcase at the school.
My group decided to try to create a multiplayer game in Java, a twist on the hunger games. Underestimating how difficult it would be to accomplish that, especially since most of us had only been coding a couple months at this point. We had grand visions of procedural generation and multiplayer and every thing working as intended. By the end of the project, we technically had everything but the game portion.

Here is an example of the character animation a team member made.

I was in charge of the multiplayer or networking of the game. We had a very vague idea of what we needed to do to get it playable by multiple people so I offered to take the helm on what turned out to be the hardest part. I wound up having to use sockets in Java and manually creating/sending/receiving packets over the network. I had many sleepless nights trying to wrap my head around this while still learning OOP principles, but was eventually able to get basic multiplayer working.

This is a project that we overscoped and underestimated, but was still able to create something that resembled our goal. If we had a couple more weeks to work on it or had undertaken this at a later time, I feel like we could've reached our original goal.
